Spanish, Korean, and Hmong have comparative adjectives, however, the words are not formed by adding the suffix
. Instead, comparative adjectives combine the word
with an adjective (e.g., He is more tall than me. They are more slow than him.).

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
/ square. Add a square to show me

Guide students through a reading of What Makes a Rainbow?
Dictate the following sentences for students to write, one at a time:
The horse ran faster than the fastest goat. Jens voice is louder than mine, but Nates voice is the loudest of all.

Read the title, modeling appropriate intonation. Point out that the title asks a question. Explain that this is a poem. Point out that the text is formatted in short lines instead of paragraphs. Ask students to point to the rainbow and name the colors they see. Ask students to listen for words that rhyme, or end with the same sounds.
For the first reading, have students echoread the text with you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can take turns reading each couplet.
Prompt students to find words with comparative and superlative suffixes
in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Point out that the words
but are not examples of words with a comparative suffix. If you remove the letters
there is no base word. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.

High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.
